ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
CONSUMER PRICE INDEX
(Computation and Changes)


    1. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) whether the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and its basis of computation reflects accurately the change in the cost of living in Singapore; and (b) whether the cost of housing, including the increase in Housing and Development Board purchase price, is taken into consideration in the computation of CPI.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Consumer Price Index is the most widely used indicator of inflation for consumption expenditure. It is a measure of average price changes for a fixed basket of goods and services commonly used by households in Singapore. This basket was derived from the household expenditure survey conducted between June 1982 and May 1983. It covered a range of household expenditures between $100 per month and $2,999 per month, and this is representative of approximately 91% of the households in Singapore. 4,573 households involving 22,000 individuals participated in the survey and the range of individual items of goods and services covered around 1,450 items.

    Hence, for the vast majority of households in Singapore, the CPI could be said to be fairly representative of the cost of living, with one important qualification - the CPI does not measure changes in consumption habits and patterns, because it measures price changes for a fixed basket of goods and services. What does this mean? This is why it is important to distinguish between the concept of cost of living changes and CPI changes.

    Perhaps the easiest way to explain this is to give an illustration. A household participated in the 1982-83 survey on an item of food consumption, for example. Let us assume the family went out to eat in 1982-83 once a week. This would be factored into the CPI base of weighting. In the intervening period, assuming the wife

Column: 1526

decided to go out to work, they had to change their style of living. They now ea out three or four times a week. This is a significant change in the style of living which affects the change in the cost o living but is not picked up by changes in the CPI.

    Another example would be a family which in 1982-83 normally travelled by public transport and, in the intervening period, because of promotion of the head of the household, was able to buy a car. This is a significant change in the style of living which is not picked up in the CPI changes. So this is a rather important distinction which Members should recognize.

    A survey is carried out once in every five years simply because it is impractical and too expensive to do it more frequently because of the vast amount of work involved. In the majority of countries which have CPI indexes, surveys are carried out once in 10 years, particularly in large countries like the United States.

    It might be of interest to Members to know of the history of CPI changes for Singapore over the last 25 years. We have indeed a remarkably good record of inflation. In the last 25 years, in only two years did we have high inflation. We have, in 1973 and 1974, inflation in the range of 20% due to very high cost of imported fuel and food because of the first oil shock. In two years, in 1980 and 1981, inflation of CPI changes was in the range of 8%, partly due to the results of the second oil shock in 1979 and partly because of Government's policy of high wage which started in that year. In the remaining 21 years, 18 of these years have CPI changes or inflation changes of less than 5% and, in 12 of these 21 years, the inflation was indeed below 2%. Last year, the inflation was 2.6% and the preceding year 1.2%. This is indeed a remarkable record due partly to a number of factors which Members might be interested to know.

    One was the very strong Singapore dollar, and this is important because approximately 70% of what we consume is imported. The other factor which is important is: we operate a free economy with practically no import duties or excise

Column: 1527

taxes on items other than petrol, liquor and tobacco. This means that we are able to import from everywhere around the world the cheapest and best goods. Of course, another important factor was the presence of the CPF which removes from immediate consumption some of the high wages introduced in the 1980-83 period.

    The second part of the question which was asked concerns whether the cost of housing, including the increase in Housing and Development Board purchase price, is taken into consideration in the computation of CPI. The answer is yes and no. No, because the purchase of houses is not considered as consumption. Therefore, the cost of houses is not factored directly into the CPI. However, the cost of housing is factored in two forms.

    Firstly, direct rentals, and the majority would be HDB rentals, would be included in the weighting for the CPI index. For owner-occupied flats or houses, the figure used would be the assessed value, ie, what the owner-occupier pays in the way of assessment or a rent imputed from that which is equivalent. Because the majority of our respondents in the survey actually occupy HDB type accommodation, the housing component of CPI is relatively small and, overall, it accounts for no more than 7% of the CPI weighting.

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Ang Kok Peng (Buona Vista): Sir, before I continue from where I stopped yesterday, let me first make it clear that I

Column: 1528

fully appreciate the excellent job done by the Ministry in housing the former street hawkers in hawker centres. The point I wish to make is that there should be some latitude in implementing the policy of resiting hawkers.

    Yesterday I cited the example of the kachang puteh man. Other examples that may bring nostalgia to hon. Members of the House are the tikar rombong, the tingting man and the pediars of bamboo ware. As long as they observe certain conditions, such as (1) the hawkers must be medically examined and found free of communicable diseases, for example, tuberculosis; (2) no re-usable utensils are used to serve the items of sale; (3) the items should not be cooked items which are likely to go bad after a short while, and any other conditions which the Ministry may impose, why not allow them to peddle their ware? After all, we still allow ice-cream pedlars to operate. I hope the Parliamentary Secretary will give due consideration to my comments.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, on a point of clarification. In replying to a question yesterday by the Member for Pasir Panjang, the Parliamentary Secretary said that the Pasir Panjang cooked food centre was being renovated and more stalls would be added and insular panels would be installed. Can I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether the Ministry of the Environment has similar plans to renovate other first-generation cooked food centres and markets managed by the Ministry of the Environment, including the one in my constituency, ie, the Lim Tua Tow market and cooked food centre which was built more than two decades ago?

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Sir, I do not have an amendment under this Head but may I add my plea, for five minutes, to what has been said by the Member for Buona Vista.

    Sir, speaking on the Budget, I mentioned about life being driven out of the streets of Singapore. I was, of course, referring to the hawkers. The Minister, however, in replying, deftly turned it to suggest that I was referring to some other life. But I am not cavilling at that. I would ask the Ministry to consider seriously whether some

Column: 1529

itinerant hawkers may not be allowed on our streets subject to conditions as the Member has pointed out. They do add colour to our life in Singapore, as has already been pointed out. The sarabat man, sitting under a tree and surrounded by people chatting away, does add colour. I would ask the Minister to consider this.

    I have one or two itinerant hawkers in my constituency and one of them, in fact, sells Chinese rojak which, may I say, is very good. He peddles this on a bicycle and I really cannot see the objection that the Ministry has to granting him a licence. The poor man is persecuted all the time and I feel very sorry for him because that is the only livelihood he knows. Can we take a more enlightened look on our itinerant hawkers?

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, I have three amendments*. I will, with your permission, Sir, range over them.

     The Chairman: Yes.
11.15 am

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, in fact, I had wanted to speak as and when the amendments come up, the first of which concerns Solid Waste Management. And the amendment that I had intended to move was under Subhead M B-02 Project 8102 of the Development Estimates - a new vehicle workshop at Eunos Industrial Estate - for which the building cost of $9.6 million had almost been expended, requiring only a $1,000 for FY 85, and this is a mere revote. In other words, I take it that this new vehicle workshop at Eunos Industrial Estate, has not only been completed but is also operational. Now, the point I wish to make concerns maintenance and the upkeep of the vehicles, ie, the garbage disposal trucks.

    I remember the previous Minister for the Environment did point out to this House that some of these garbage trucks should have been properly maintained and that the refuse or solid waste collected by these trucks should have been properly kept. So we had this campaign on the use of plastic

Column: 1530

bags. As a result, Sir, most households, if not all, were urged to wrap up the refuse in plastic bags for collection and disposal by these workers. Sir, the point here is that these workers, I understand, are very few and less and less of them will be available because this is a job which very few will take in a situation of tight employment.

    But what happens is that, from time to time, when one follows behind these refuse trucks, one notices that this solid waste has, in fact, become liquid in one way or another, and therefore the liquid drips down from the truck, leaving behind a long trail of watery waste. In actual fact, Sir, this morning I was asked by some good friends, hon. Members in this House, if I had come to Parliament House via High Street. I said yes. Because our arrival time was not the same, I did not notice but some of my good friends noticed that one refuse truck suffered this problem; the truck was dripping liquid waste as it went along.

    Sir, I was going to ask what steps are being taken to maintain and upkeep these vehicles, and what encouragement or further encouragement has been given, by way of campaigns or whatever, that could be directed at all households, be it in the HDB estates or private housing estates. It is important to know that Singapore, with a high density of population living in, say, 5,000 per sq km, endemic diseases like cholera could well spread very fast. So an awareness of the importance of using these plastic bags to wrap up whatever refuse or waste could be mounted so that we will not have a situation where an endemic disease is spread very fast.

    I liken this to the fly menace that I brought to the attention of this House and the Minister for the Environment, in his reply, said that he had visited the refuse disposal ground at Lorong Halus and found that, because there were not enough workers, the contractors did not supply enough earth and it became a breeding ground for flies. Therefore, we can see that, in a place like Singapore, if environmental action concerning public

Column: 1531

health is not properly taken, we may face a very serious situation.

    Sir, I come to the question of cleansing vehicles. I notice, in the Development Estimates, there is a provision of $7 million for the purchase of new mechanical sweepers. This would help reduce the dependence on manual labour and to cut down costs. But, on the other hand, I think we should have more mechanization as far as the sweeping and collection of garbage is concerned.

    Sir, I now come to this question of the development and improvement of market and hawker sites. I was a bit surprised and taken aback at the suggestion to stop building these wet markets. I do not think it would be a good idea if the Ministry of the Environment, or for that matter the Housing and Development Board, were to scrap wet markets. Wet markets have been part of the way of life of Singapore. Just now the Member for Braddell Heights mentioned his problem of the old market in Lim Tua Tow Road. I know that market very well. It was reconstructed and renovated, and so is Simon Road Market in Serangoon Gardens. What I wish to point out, Sir, is this, In a wet market there are wet and dry goods. It is a good meeting place for housewives to gather. Do hon. Members in this House not agree with me that they find the market-place an interesting place because they meet a lot of their constituents? On Sundays, I see my good friend, the hon. Member for Changi, going to the market at Hougang Avenue 7. It is being renovated. And I am pleased to get a feedback from him. The goods there are wet and dry. I would appeal very strongly to the Minister for the Environment to impress upon his colleague the Hon. Minister for National Development not to stop building wet markets.

    If wet markets are not built, I am afraid you entail higher costs to the people. Let me give an example, Sir. If one wishes to shop in cool comfort in a supermarket, inevitably one has to pay a price. In a wet market, Sir, one can walk through from stall to stall and even choose. But in the supermarket, things are all pre-packed to the exact weight and exact price. The

Column: 1532

choice is just a matter of quantity and cool comfort. But that cool comfort will not last long for sooner than the customer steps out of the supermarket, he or she comes back to square one. So, I would say that the wet market, together with the hawker centre, should be built. Otherwise, Sir, I anticipate that many stallholders will not be able to eke out a living if they continue to be market stallholders. The question is: do we want the situation where we say we are caring and concerned but we are forgetting these people?

    Then, Sir, another problem that I wish to address this House concerns the resettlement of pig farmers, vegetable farmers and other residents, not only from Punggol but a lot of other places. Many of these people have been farming the land for generations and when clearance comes, they come to the MPs, "Please help us obtain a hawker stall to sell cooked food or market produce." These requests are sent to the Ministry of the Environment, Hawkers Department. Sometimes they help when the question of hardship can be established, but most times they say, "No, it is not possible." Why is it not possible? "Because the rules are there on grounds of hardship," and so on and so forth. But it is more because these people have been given adequate compensation.

    I highlight this with a case in which I had to fight very hard, the only case which I succeeded on grounds of hardship. One farrier, who was widowed, was compensated with an amount of about $130,000. With that compensation she bought a flat at Lorong Ah Soo, which is Hougang South, in Paya Lebar. And she came to me and it took me more than a year before I could impress upon the Minister concerned that here was a genuine case of hardship.

    So I would make another strong plea to the Ministry of the Environment to take a careful look in the resettlement of people whose livelihood is affected in a quantifiable sense, and if necessary a more than sympathetic consideration should be given, rather than saying, "Look, these people have been adequately compensated for, and maybe we can help them by way of giving them a shop-house in an HDB estate." Far from it. If they have a

Column: 1533

shop-house, Sir, my contention is that they would have to spend quite a lot of money into the business, not forgetting that the compensation they get would have to go towards paying for the flat. But if they were given, say, a hawker stall, then less capital will be needed, and if it fails the chances are the loss will not be so great. Only then they could try and turn to or adapt themselves to a new environment and make a living through hawking. Now, I make this plea, Sir, because I notice that the provision under this subhead is hardly sufficient.
11.30 am

    Sir, talking about the affected farmers, there is another amendment which I moved, and this concerns the development of farm lands at Punggol and South Seletar. It comes under the Agricultural Planning and Development Services. We have heard from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment that pig farming will be phased out and there is an implementation plan. First of all, I would like to know what progress, if any, has been made in this regard. If there has been progress made in the implementation plan, ie, that it is being considered, contrived or whatever, is the Ministry now ready to disclose the plans to this House?

    But, Sir, looking at the problem in another perspective, ie, the farmers in phase 1 have been phased out completely and they have moved out, big tracts of land have been left unattended. We had occasion to hear from PAP Members on both sides of the House making the point that some of their constituents who had moved out, say, from Bukit Batok, notice that these lands have not been put to good use. And we have also heard the answer from the Hon. Minister for National Development when he explained that it is not possible to just move quickly into an area that has been vacated. I can well understand him. It takes time for conceptual planning from the drawing board to be translated into reality.

    In this respect, the hon. Member for Chua Chu Kang has also suggested that these lands that have been laid to waste,

Column: 1534

so to speak, could be put to good use. In this regard, could the Hon. Minister for the Environment not consider leasing out these lands for some other agricultural purposes or development which will not cause any pollution? For example, Singaporeans have a name for eating durians and every year millions of dollars are being spent. Why can we not have some durian plantations in Singapore? And with that in mind, I heard the Minister of State for Defence say that the Ministry of Defence needs land for training purposes. So if durian cultivation is allowed now, the saplings in the initial stages will become sturdy trees in years to come. Why can we not keep these lands which make good training ground for the Defence Ministry? But lest the Minister of State jumps and say, "On a point of clarification", may I say, Sir, I am aware that in land scarce Singapore, every bit of land is important. And whenever it is necessary, we can whiffle them down say, from 80 sq km, it has to come down to 60 sq km, or it may be much less. So we may have to whittle them down to smaller areas. But I do not think he can dispute that in the interim, say, 3-5 years, before these lands are really needed for housing development or whatever, these lands could be put to optimum use. We have been stressing on optimum utilization of land. Here is one area, Sir, that I would like the Minister for the Environment to point out that they have.

     Mr Tang See Chim (Chua Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the hon. Member for Punggol has touched on pig farming, and as I have two amendments on Subheads MF-01 and M F-02, may I have your permission to speak?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, there are still some 600 pig farms in my constituency. These farmers would like to know what is the Government policy with regard to pig farming. Although there have been vague pronouncements, especially one or two by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, there has been no clear-cut Government policy on the subject. This is not fair to the farmers. They want to know where they stand and what is the Government's policy on pig farming.

Column: 1535



    Sir, I had a meeting with representatives of the pig farmers in my constituency on the 11th of this month. The farmers are prepared to be resettled. They know that pig farming is a pollutive industry. They appreciate that it will have to be phased out. But they just want to know when and for how long they can carry on pig farming.

    Sir, in connection with resettlement which they know they have to undergo, they want a period of at least one year between the announcement and the final moving out so that they have sufficient time in which to phase down their operations. During the transitional period, they also want the Ministry to monitor very closely the position so that farmers who are under resettlement will not be exploited by the middlemen. For example, they want the Ministry to monitor very closely the import of live pigs so that there would not be a glut in the market whereby they may not be able to wind down their business in an orderly manner. Furthermore, the Government should look into the possibility of how to provide an alternative means of livelihood to those farmers of advanced years and without children to support them.

    Sir, in the debate on resettlement, I have touched on the question of expeditious payment of compensation as well as requesting the Minister to reinstate the previous policy of giving a 3-room flat free to farmers who hold farm licences. I would repeat this request on behalf of my farmers in Chua Chu Kang, and indeed on behalf of all farmers who are being resettled.

     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have one amendment on the matter under discussion and another amendment* on hawker control. Can I take them together?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee: Sir, at the Budget sitting last year, I raised the question of collection and disposal of garbage

Column: 1536

in Housing Board estates. Under this year's Development Estimates, $130 million is set aside for solid waste management, out of which $102 million is earmarked for a second refuse incineration plant. I do not know whether we are getting our priorities right. It appears to me that we are not giving enough priority to tackling the problem at source, ie, garbage handling at the hundreds of rubbish chutes in Housing Board estates and private high-rise apartments.

    Sir, the Hon. Minister has expressed concern that his Ministry is facing a problem of manpower shortage for obvious reasons. This problem of manpower shortage will be further compounded in the 1990s when 80% of our population live in Housing Board high-rise apartments. Our present garbage collection and disposal system does not take into consideration the appalling stinking working conditions and health hazards faced by our cleansing workers. Householders are also to be blamed for indiscriminately disposing the garbage without giving a second thought to the occupational hazards of the cleansing workers.

    The recent campaign to encourage householders to use plastic bags is ineffective. This method is only good for low-rise buildings. Garbage placed in plastic bags thrown down from a high-rise building will burst on impact. I would suggest that the Ministry liaises with other public bodies to explore various ways to improve on the design of rubbish chutes in high-rise buildings which can be integrated into a mechanized garbage collection and disposal system.

    In Japan and Switzerland, garbage is packaged at source by using a simple mechanical device which, I believe, can be modified to fit into our existing rubbish chutes and bin compounds. Perhaps we could also consider giving incentives to private developers of high-rise apartments to install such equipment in their buildings. The Jurong Town Corporation had at one time granted concessions to industrial undertakings which install anti-pollution equipment or measures in their factories.

Column: 1537

We can increase the number of refuse incinerator disposal sites and collection vehicles, but it still stinks all the way.

    Sir, coming to my second amendment, ie, hawker control, we have over the years built up a very high standard of environmental public health. Stringent health controls are placed on hawkers in the preparation of food and food centres. Unfortunately, we do not seem to have much control over the pricing of food served at hawker centres. Only recently, the cost of a plate of fried rice or fried noodles increased from $1.20 to $1.50, an increase of 25% in some food stalls. The reasons given were the increase in petrol prices, road tax and the impending increase in taxi fares. Come July the 1st, when the NWC recommendations are announced, I am sure there will be another round of price increases in hawker food. Some hawkers make use of every opportunity to increase prices, and in many cases they are not justifiable. Even if there is a drop in the price of rice, pork or other food items, the price of hawker food remains the same. There is no mechanism to regulate or control increases in food prices at hawker centres. One possible method is to make every hawker state the prices of food sold on his licence application. On renewal, if there is any upward revision in price, he must get prior approval, otherwise his licence will not be approved. This method of price control is practised by many factory canteens which subsidize their canteen operators. With computerization, Sir, there should be no difficulty in implementing such a scheme.

    Sir, to support my contention that price increases by some hawkers are unjustified, I would give an example of the disparity in price and quality of food sold at hawker centres and hawker stalls in HDB coffee shops. The rental paid by a hawker in an HDB coffee shop is many times more than the rental paid by one in a hawker centre, yet the food sold by the former is of better quality for the same price. Some of these stalls are close to hawker centres. They have to compete to survive. If the Government continues to subsidize rentals

Column: 1538

of hawker stalls in hawker centres, then it should exercise some control over prices of food sold in these centres.

    Sir, I would suggest that when all roadside hawkers are properly resited, the Ministry should reconsider the present system of charging rentals, possibly renting out by tender in the open market. This would ensure free competition and may not necessarily result in frequent increases in food prices at hawker centres provided we have a better reason to control the increase in prices of food sold in hawker centres.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, first, I rise* to protest the heavy and continued pollution from Sungei Whampoa.      Mr Lee Yock Suan: I would like to take this opportunity to elaborate on the policy, as stated in the recent Budget Statement, that the Government will be more flexible in administering the repatriation of foreign workers.

    Businessmen and employers should not misconstrue this policy to mean that the Government is reopening the tap to allow more unskilled foreign workers to come in. The bulk of NTS workers in manufacturing have already left by the end of last year. The remaining ones, who were granted extension until 1986, will be leaving over the next two years - as and when their work permits expire. Except for those who are employed as domestic help and in the construction industry and shipyards, all NTS workers in other sectors have already been repatriated(2).

    My Ministry will however try to strike a reasonable balance between the long-term goal of reducing dependence on unskilled foreign workers and the need to ensure that repatriation will not affect economic growth. Thus:-

They have been constantly reminded to upgrade and adjust their operations to prepare for the day when they will not have access to foreign workers.

    - My Ministry will continue to restrict the number of new foreign workers to be admitted. New recruitments will be allowed only selectively to meet the needs for critical skills or to accommodate temporary shortages, particularly in manufacturing, hotels, shipyards and construction and for domestic help.
